awd_titl_txt: Thermodynamics of Strongly Coupled Non-Relativistic Matter.
awd_abstract_narration:
First-principles investigations of neutron and nuclear matter are at the forefront of research activities in nuclear physics and take ample advantage of the recent advances in high-performance computing. This project will lay the groundwork for finite-temperature studies of nuclear physics by pursuing the systematic study of strongly-coupled Fermi systems and by testing this approach with related few- and many-body problems in atomic physics. The numerical methods developed here focus on nonperturbative aspects of the nuclear many-body problem and the results are expected to impact other fields such as atomic and condensed matter physics, high-energy physics and astrophysics. The group will establish a database of Monte Carlo configurations that will serve the scientific community in the USA and abroad.

This project will promote an interdisciplinary study employing advanced first-principles calculations in several fields, ranging from nuclear physics to condensed matter and atomic physics. This will present unique opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students to develop a broad understanding of various physical systems and perform creative multidisciplinary research. The database developed here will provide hands-on tools useful for teaching nonperturbative numerical methods for students worldwide. Education at the undergraduate level will benefit the local Computational Astronomy and Physics Research Experience for Undergraduates (CAP-REU) program.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported the exploration of the thermodynamic properties of strongly coupled quantum matter. This kind of matter is special because interactions among particles play a crucial role, and because it is generically found in a wide range of situations in Nature. Those situations cover the very small (like quarks inside protons and neutrons, or in the lab-prepared ultracold atomic gases) to the very large (neutron matter in the high densities found inside certain stars). This project focused, in particular, on non-relativistic matter, which is a regime of direct relevance to nuclear, atomic, and condensed matter physics (as opposed to high-energy physics where accounting for Einstein's special relativity effects is essential) which presents challenges of its own.

Characterizing the thermodynamics of matter entails calculating in detail its behavior as a function of temperature, density, polarization, interaction strength, and other parameters. This project studied matter constrained to 1D and 2D (comparing directly with ultracold atom experiments in the latter case and predicting the equation of state in the former), in the presence of spin polarization (in 1D and 3D) and mass imbalance (in 3D), in external traps (e.g. harmonic potentials and hard-wall containers), and for multicomponent systems (in 1D and 2D). The attached figure shows the density equation of state of 1D fermions for varying interaction strength, which was surprisingly absent from the literature and is one of the first outcomes of this project.

The work involved in this project is challenging because it is not generally amenable to paper-and-pencil calculations and must, therefore, be carried out with heavy computational methods. In many cases, those methods needed to be developed from scratch or imported from other areas [such as from the theory of strong interactions, namely quantum chromodynamics (QCD)]. In particular, novel approaches for external trapping potentials were developed as part of this project (e.g. using non-uniform lattices for harmonic traps and Fourier acceleration for hard-wall potentials). In some especially challenging cases, such as those involving finite polarization and/or mass imbalance, QCD-inspired ideas based on so-called analytic continuation were successfully applied for the first time to generate non-perturbative predictions.

In addition to the scientific and methodological outcomes, the training of several graduate, undergraduate, and high-school students was supported by this project, either directly or indirectly, given that this was the PI's first grant ever as junior faculty at UNC-CH. Students W. J. Porter and M. D. Hoffman were the PI's first Ph.D. students and as such played a central role in this project. They are scheduled to defend their dissertations, based on this work, before the end of the 2016-2017 academic year. Two other students (C. R. Shill and A. C. Loheac) are on track to defend their dissertations within the next two years.

Finally, the investigations pursued here generated enough insight into quantum matter (and the methods to tackle it) that it resulted in new avenues of research for the PI and others. Those avenues are the focus of current and planned projects and include, for instance, entanglement properties of 1D and 3D quantum matter (partially explored within this project and of relevance to quantum computing; shown in attached image) as well as the adaptation and application of stochastic quantization methods (namely complex Langevin dynamics) to address the especially challenging case of repulsive interactions and polarized matter (where the so-called sign problem has been a major roadblock to progress across all areas involving quantum physics).
